speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the feeding intolerance? Was it sudden or did it start gradually, and have you noticed any other symptoms such as diarrhea or blood in the stool?

speaker: Patient
text: It started right away, I wasn't able to latch properly and I've been spitting up a lot, it's hard to tell if it's milk or bile, and my mom says I've been really fussy and not interested in feeding, even when she's trying to give me a bottle.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your fussiness and lack of interest in feeding? Is it constant or does it seem to come and go, and have you noticed any other changes in your overall behavior, such as being more alert or sleepy than usual?

speaker: Patient
text: It's always been like that, to be honest. I just seem to get really uncomfortable and fussy after feeding, and it's hard for my mom to get me to calm down and eat again. Sometimes I'll seem fine for a bit, but then I'll start fussing and spitting up again.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your overall behavior when you're not feeling comfortable or after feeding? Are you more irritable or restless, or do you seem to be in pain? Also, I'd like to perform a physical examination to check for any signs of dehydration or discomfort. Can you please undress from the waist down for me?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to explain, but I just seem really uncomfortable when I'm full, and I get really upset. My mom says I arch my back and try to lift my head up when I'm feeling this way, but I don't know what's going on.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly what your mom means by you arching your back and trying to lift your head up when you're feeling uncomfortable? Is this a movement you make on your own, or does your mom notice it happening? Also, can you please point out to me any areas of your abdomen that feel tender to the touch, or any other areas that seem particularly uncomfortable to you?

speaker: Patient
text: I think I arch my back and try to lift my head up when I feel really uncomfortable, like when I'm full or when I'm feeling really upset. My mom says I do it on my own, but sometimes she's there to catch me when I do it. I don't really know what it means, but it feels like my body is trying to tell me something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you point out to me exactly where you arch your back and try to lift your head up, is it in a specific position or movement? Also, I'd like to examine your abdomen to check for any tenderness or discomfort. Can you please hold still for me while I gently press on your abdomen?

speaker: Patient
text: It's when I'm lying down, I think. My back arches and I try to lift my head up, like I'm trying to get away from something. It's a pretty subtle movement, but my mom says it's noticeable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you were born and how quickly you were able to start feeding after birth? Was it a normal, quick transition, or did you seem to struggle with latching or feeding in general? Also, have you noticed any changes in your stool or urine output since you started showing signs of feeding intolerance and bilious vomiting?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really remember much about being born, I just kind of... woke up, I guess. My mom says I was able to latch on pretty quickly, but I don't really remember that part. As for changes in my stool or urine output, my mom says my stool is really thin and watery, and she's had to change my diapers a lot lately. And, um, my mom says my urine output is pretty low, so she's been having to give me extra feedings to make sure I'm getting enough to drink.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's observations of your stool and urine output? Is she noticing any changes in the color or consistency of your stool, and is she concerned about your urine output being low? And, I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Urine Output and Stool Sample.

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like we have some concerning test results. The double bubble sign on the Upper GI Series is a classic indicator of duodenal atresia, a congenital condition where the duodenum is blocked. I'd like to ask a few more questions to confirm this diagnosis and rule out any other possibilities. Can you tell me more about your mother's feeding technique? Was she using a nipple shield, and if so, for how long? And have you noticed any other symptoms like abdominal pain or gas during feeding? Also, I'd like to request another test: REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound of the abdomen to confirm the presence of duodenal atresia.
